content: The "Reforming Alternatives to Incarceration and Sentencing to Establish a Better Path for Youth Act of 2015" is also known as the "RAISE Act of 2015". It includes a safety valve for nonviolent youth. Section 3553 of title 18, United States Code, allows courts to impose a sentence below a statutory minimum for youth convicted of nonviolent offenses if it would result in substantial injustice and is not necessary for public protection. The "RAISE Act of 2015" includes this provision as a safety valve for nonviolent youth. The court must provide notice and an opportunity to respond before imposing a sentence below the statutory minimum for youth convicted of nonviolent offenses. This provision does not limit any right to appeal. The term 'nonviolent offense' refers to a Federal criminal offense that is not a crime of violence or a sex offense. SEC. 3. EARLY RELEASE AND HOME CONFINEMENT FOR YOUTH. Section 3624 of title 18, United States Code is amended to allow for early release and home confinement for youth prisoners. The amendment includes provisions for the duration of home confinement based on the term of imprisonment. The amendment to Section 3624 of title 18, United States Code allows for early release and home confinement for youth prisoners. Home confinement duration is based on the term of imprisonment, with a presumption in favor of direct release to home confinement unless specific findings are made by the Director of the Bureau of Prisons. Placement in a community correction center cannot be used solely due to mental health diagnosis, and prisoners on home confinement cannot be ordered to pay for electronic monitoring. The amendment to Section 3624 of title 18, United States Code allows for early release and home confinement for youth prisoners who have served half or more of their term for nonviolent offenses without recent violent conduct violations. Prisoners on home confinement cannot be ordered to pay for electronic monitoring. The term 'youth' refers to individuals 21 years of age or younger at the time of the offense, and 'nonviolent offense' excludes crimes of violence or sex offenses. The amendment allows for supervised release consideration for youth prisoners who have served half or more of their term for nonviolent offenses without recent violent conduct violations. The amendment allows for supervised release consideration for youth prisoners who have served at least 20 years, based on extraordinary and compelling reasons, including rehabilitation efforts. The amendment allows for a reduction in mandatory life sentences for youth offenders based on rehabilitation efforts and mitigating circumstances. The sentencing court must consider the age of the youth in determining the appropriate sentence. The amendment allows for a reduction in mandatory life sentences for youth offenders by considering their age in determining the appropriate sentence. SEC. 5. SMARTER PROBATION FOR YOUTH. Section 3565 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include a special rule for technical violations of probation. The maximum punishment for such violations is 30 days imprisonment for the first violation, 60 days for the second violation, and 90 days for the third or subsequent violation. The United States Sentencing Commission is directed to review and potentially amend the Federal sentencing guidelines and policy statements. The United States Sentencing Commission is directed to review and potentially amend the Federal sentencing guidelines and policy statements related to the revocation of probation and supervised release under section 3565 of title 18, United States Code. SEC. 6. Specialized housing and programs for youth are designated in correctional facilities to separate youth from other offenders and provide specific education, training, and mental health programs. SEC. 7. Pilot programs for youth are established. The Bureau of Prisons will establish pilot programs for youth in at least 10 judicial districts, including mentorship, government service, and service to vulnerable animals. The Department of Health and Human Services, the Department of Veterans Affairs, and the Department of Justice will establish programs to equip youth with skills to provide training and therapy to animals seized by Federal law enforcement and organizations that help vulnerable animals. The Attorney General will establish pilot programs for high-risk youth to avoid criminal conviction and for victimized youth who have been abused or trafficked. The programs provide intensive case management and comprehensive community services for youth in vulnerable situations. A reporting requirement to Congress on the results of the pilot programs will include cost savings, participant numbers, and recidivism rates. The report to Congress on pilot programs will detail cost savings, participant numbers, and recidivism rates. Definitions in this section clarify "youth" as individuals under 21 at the time of the offense, and "nonviolent offense" as excluding violent crimes and sex offenses. SEC. 8. RETROACTIVE EFFECT. This Act and its amendments apply to youth regardless of when they enter the Federal criminal justice system.
